Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: It is time for the daily morning prayer service in the main chapel, as scheduled in the convent's regular order of the day.
Story:
The morning sun filtered through the convent window as I hunched over my laptop, eyes scanning lines of code. A user had reported a minor UI glitch—nothing catastrophic, but it nagged at me. The workaround was simple, but I knew my team expected a permanent fix, and I prided myself on thoroughness. My fingers hovered over the keyboard, ready to dive in, when the chapel bell tolled, its sound echoing through the halls. It was time for morning prayer, a sacred part of our daily rhythm, and my sisters would expect me to be present, kneeling in silent devotion.

My heart pounded with the familiar tug-of-war. The world outside demanded my technical expertise, my commitment to excellence. Inside these walls, I was called to humility, to set aside worldly concerns and join my sisters in prayer. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure mount. If I left now, the bug would linger, my team might be disappointed, and users would continue to stumble. If I stayed, I’d miss the prayer, betraying the discipline and unity of our community. My hands trembled as I closed my eyes, caught between two worlds, unsure which to serve in this moment.
